author: sky.cactus
content: > The motivation section should explain why this needs to be a Standard rather than just a Good Idea since it isn't immediately obvious.  A standard is valuable when there is a many-to-many relationship between parties.  An example of something that needs a standard is web pages because there are many browsers that come and go over time and there are many web pages on the internet that come and go over time.  In order for all web pages to work on all browsers, we need a standard.  If you have a one to many relationship or a one to one relationship, then you don't need a standard and instead just have a Good Idea that you can implement.

author: sky.cactus
content: Thoughts on the wording of that?  I find myself typing it out a lot, figured I could refine it and save it somewhere.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would like to point broken links at some 404 page rather than a GitHub issue or pull request, any thoughts on what to put in for a placeholder?

author: sky.cactus
content: The goal is to make it obvious and easy to find when these old EIPs are pointing at PRs and Issues that are not EIPs.

author: sky.cactus
content: cc <@!425279588009246720> <@!543900561460822016> to see if you have thoughts on where these broken EIP links should point.

author: sky.cactus
content: Recap of the situation: People have `[EIP-123](...)` where `123` is not a valid EIP.  Usually it is just some pull request or GitHub issue that never even made it to draft status.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would *rather* have those link to a 404 page than link to an issue or PR, as it will make it much easier for us to find and clean them up later, and it will be more clear to users that there is a problem (hopefully).

author: sky.cactus
content: There are about 35 instances of this problem across the repository.

author: axic3354
content:
> Thoughts on the wording of that?  I find myself typing it out a lot, figured I could refine it and save it somewhere.
<@!301186049323958275> looks good, you had another sentence that somethings are better documented as part of the project / proprietary product. Maybe include that too?

Ideally something like this goes into EIP-1 where it describes the idea stage.

author: axic3354
content: Even if something starts out as a proprietary doc, if more products adopt it, it may make sense to turn into an eip at that stage. I'd include this clarification too.

author: axic3354
content: What we are trying to avoid is serving as a documentation place for random projects, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't know that people are intentionally creating EIPs as a form of documentation or advertising.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think some of them really don't understand that you don't have to standardize everything.

author: axic3354
content: I have no idea about their motivation but extending your explanation with those suggestions may help them consider it better.

author: axic3354
content: As long as it is put into EIP-1 and you don't need to copy it to every single review

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree with you that I shouldn't be changing text in this PR, but the links are (IMO) bad links to start with and by being explicit about that it makes it easier for us to find them later.

author: sky.cactus
content: I wonder what happens if I just do `[EIP-123]()`?

author: sky.cactus
content: Because the more tedious process will never be done I suspect.

author: axic3354

author: sky.cactus
content: I would rather see things hard fail, because that is more likely to be fixed by the authors, than if things just work incorrectly.

author: sky.cactus
content:

I think you are more optimistic that I am that we'll see the necessary changes to the EIP validation bot and merge bot.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Currently, my PR has a bunch of failures due to `[EIP-123](./eip-123.md)` resulting in a 404 (expected).  There are 3 options to resolve that:
1. Excise all such links from EIPs.
2. Revert those links back to pointing at pull requests or whatever other broken thing they were previously pointing at.
3. Deadify all of the links by changing them to `[EIP-123]`

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm leaning toward 3.  That is what EIP-1 had prior to my PR.

author: axic3354
content: Will someone post a clear explanation of what those statuses mean?

author: madeof_tin7509
content:
Draft
The first formally tracked stage of an EIP. This EIP is merged when properly formatted and is still under development.

Review
The EIP author marks an EIP as ready for and requesting Peer review.

Stagnant
Any EIP in DRAFT or REVIEW that has been inactive for a period of 6 months or greater is automaticaly moved to theSTANGNANT status.

EIP Authors are notified of any automatic change to the status of their EIP

Withdrawn
The EIP Author(s) decided to withdraw the proposal.

Living
A special status for EIPs that are designed to be continually updated and not reach a ‚ÄúFinal‚Äù state. This includes EIP-1 and other registry EIPs.

author: axic3354
content:
I'm phrasing this based on #2941:

And editor can only mark it `status="Withdrawn" reason="no activity"` . Hopefully if someone implements a bot, the bot can do it, but bots wont write themselves (at least not yet). I do not think this is a political step as long it is clearly stated in EIP-1.

`status="Withdrawn" reason="by author"` can only be set by the author, again not an editor decision.

author: axic3354
content:
Okay here's the idea how to clear up the README <> EIP-1 <> *frontpage on eips.ethereum.org* mess:
- Change EIP-1 so that it consists of clear chapters, one being "Contributing"
- Explain all the tech steps (in the readme now) in Contributing
- Merge the anchor headings PR: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2581
- Replace most of what the README and the *frontpage on eips.ethereum.org* with a link to https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPs/eip-1#contributing
